lg.l: The kauri lifts its stately head, Kauri … stately head. It was a settler commonplace to refer to kauri as the “monarch of the New Zealand forest” (i.e. T. Kirk, The Forest Flora of New Zealand, 1889). with verdure over-crowned,
And looks down on all the other trees that in the woods are found;
Without a branch full fifty feet, Without a branch full fifty feet. Kauri shed their lower branches after several decades of growth. uprears its mighty stem,
Then spreads abroad its giant arms, as if protecting them.
The oak is England’s boast and pride; its fame the poets sing,
And yet ‘tis but a dwarf beside New Zealand’s Forest King.
A sapling in the woods it grew, a thousand years Thousand years. Kauri were renowned for their ability to grow to an extreme age. ago,
And all the time defied the storms and fiercest winds that blow.
Although, now in its sturdy prime, unbent by length of years,
And heedless of the tempest’s might, one foe the monarch fears:
The bushman marches through the woods, destruction in his tracks,
And soon the mighty tree must fall beneath the woodman’s axe.
Blow follows blow with steady skill; the gap grows deep and wide,
While thick and fast the flying chips fall down on every side.
A crack, then one terrific crash is heard for miles around,
And now the monarch of the woods lies stretched upon the ground.
The kauri grew, while in the earth, the axe unsmelted lay,
Nor could the wisest in the land, foretell its work to-day.
But fate selected axe and man to lay the monarch low,
And when, or how, our death may come, nor you nor I can know.
